questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. Which statement about the interface is true?
//IMG//

discussion.content: The interface is set to trunk unconditionally. The only time I have seen no response from show interface trunk is when the trunk has no line protocol and is down. Answer C is correct.
NO SORRY if unconditional the interface needs to be down for the output to be blank otherwise the port will go into inconsistent because of spanning tree
IF NEIGH IS ACCESS PORT, OR DOWN WILL SHOW BLANK CONF

Correct answer is C.
I've verified it on real equipment - Catalyst 4500

Agree. I've tried the simple topology in the PT:
SW1 fa0/1 <-> SW2 fa0/1
1. SW1: fa0/1 interface in trunk mode 
 SW2: fa0/1 interface in access mode
 sh in tru on SW1:
SW1#sh int tru
Port Mode Encapsulation Status Native vlan
Fa0/1 on 802.1q trunking 1

Port Vlans allowed on trunk
Fa0/1 34,36,519

Port Vlans allowed and active in management domain
Fa0/1 34,36,519

Port Vlans in spanning tree forwarding state and not pruned
Fa0/1 519
SW2; int fa0/1 shutdown
sh int tru on SW1:
SW1#sh int tru


SW1#

The PT isn't a real equipment but in simple cases it works like a real network equipment.
If the other side is an access port the interface would not show in "show vlan" but it would show in "show int trunk" (just lab'd it with 2 3560s) So answer B doesn't make sense. Has to be C

Ans is C
interface is goes down.
https://vceguide.com/which-statement-about-the-interface-is-true/

choices.B: The other side of the interface is set as access
choices.A: The interface needs to shutdown configured
choices.D: The switchport command is missing from the configuration

discussion.content:
The question is "determine the reason"
Answer is A.

It must be Letter C. here an example:

Switch#show int f0/24 status
Port Name Status Vlan Duplex Speed Type
Fa0/24 err-disabled 1 auto auto 10/100BaseTX

questions.question_text: After you connect a host to switch port G0/1, the port error disabled. Which command can you enter to determine the reason?

choices.A: R2 does not have a route to 10.10.1.1/32 in its routing table
choices.C: Communication between VRRP members is encrypted using md5
choices.B: R2 becomes master if R1 reboots or track in R1 does not fail
choices.D: R1 has a route to 10.10.1/32 in its routing table

discussion.content: Answer D will be the correct one if R1 is the active router, but the question doesn't show that This is unclear question everyone answer it should have the full point

comments.content: how we can know that? we only see the tracking statement in the config not actual route.
The question states that R1 is currently master. We must assume that R1 has a route because if it didn't, R2 would be master.

discussion.content: . R1 has a route to 10.10.1.1/32 in its routing table.

Yes it is correct. VTP primary server: only the primary server is able to create / modify / delete VLANs. This is a great change as you can no longer “accidently” wipe all VLANs like you could with VTP version 1 or 2.
•Extended VLANs: you can now synchronize VLANs in the extended VLAN range (1006 – 4094).
•Private VLANs: if you have VLANs that are configured as private VLANs then you can synchronize them with VTPv3.
•RSPAN VLANs: remote SPAN VLANs can now be synchronized.
•MST Support: one of the problems of MST is that you had to configure each switch manually. With VTPv3, MST configurations are synchronized.
•Authentication improvements: VTPv3 has more secure methods for authentication.
•VTP mode off: If you didn’t want to use VTP for version 1 or 2 then you had to use the transparent mode. VTPv3 can be disabled globally or per interface.
•Compatibility: VTP version 3 is compatible with version 2, not version 1.

In addition, only one server per domain can be prompted to be a primary server.

client and secondary server devices receive a configuration from a primary server. A secondary server stores the received configuration in a local permanent storage space (for example, NVRAM) and updates other devices in the same domain and for the same instance. In the case of VTP version 1 or VTP version 2, a server can be manually configured via command-line interface (CLI) or Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP). In VTP version 3, a secondary server cannot be configured manually but can receive updates, similar to a device owning the client role.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/collateral/switches/catalyst-6500-series-switches/solution_guide_c78_508010.html
can anyone verify this is correct ?

choices.D: It supports the propagation of private VLANs
choices.B: It stores the VTP domain password securely as a SHA-1 hash
choices.A: It supports the use of AES to encrypt VTP messaging
choices.C: It adds an FCS field at the end of each VTP frame for consistency checking
choices.E: It can be configured to allow only one VTP server to make changes to the VTP domain

questions.question_text: Which two options are advantages of deploying VTPv3? (Choose two.)

choices.D: It enables multiple switch ports to share a single master configuration
choices.B: It uses a single IP address to communicate with the network
choices.A: It groups multiple switch ports as a single EtherChannel
choices.E: It allows multiple switches to operate as a single switch
choices.C: It monitors multiple switches from a central console

comments.content:
yes - correct is :
B. It uses a single IP address to communicate with the network
E. It allows multiple switches to operate as a single switch
